Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A New Infrastructure for Monitoring Social Class Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1357488
David Grusky
Stanford University

SES-1357442
Michael Macy
Cornell University

Over the last 15 years, an ever larger and more diverse population is choosing to interact using social media that record the digital traces of their communications, a development that opens up unprecedented opportunities to study the network foundation of social class relations. Although there is a long tradition of research examining whether social classes in the United States are well-formed, it has been based exclusively on survey and Census data and, by necessity, has ignored the network foundations of class structure and formation. This research takes advantage of the rising amount of interaction with social media to examine that network structure at population scale. The resulting methods will provide the basis for a new and novel research infrastructure for investigating inter-personal interaction within and between social classes in the United States.

By using data from a complete crawl of U.S. Twitter users, it becomes possible to measure class barriers to interpersonal interaction. The centerpiece of this approach is the development of methods to measure the class situation of users with profile data, lexical analysis of message content, and housing valuations for geo-located users. To supplement and validate these behavioral measures, a survey will be administered to a random sample of network edges. A similar analysis of Facebook users will be carried out. The resulting data will be used to complete the first network-based analyses of the extent and patterning of the U.S. class structure. In conventional ?static analyses? of the class structure, the size of inter-class differences in behaviors and attitudes (e.g., childrearing practices, political attitudes) is emphasized, while the patterning of inter-class contact and networks that link classes together is ignored. The key question, therefore, is whether the proposed network analyses of class yield a different portrait of the structure of social classes than the static analyses that have dominated decades of class research in the U.S. At the same time, some network-based analyses of class have been attempted in the past, analyses that have relied on an idiosyncratic range of network behaviors that may be discerned with survey methods (especially, assortative mating where people marry persons with similar education and occupational characteristics, and intergenerational social mobility). The analyses undertaken here will reveal whether social media reduces class barriers to interaction relative to the level of class homophily (the tendency of people to associate with similar people) revealed in face-to-face networks available in survey data. These analyses will provide the foundation of a new network-based analysis of class structure.

Broader Impacts

If class barriers are comparatively weak in on-line interactions, standard measurements of class structure will provide an increasingly misleading portrait of civil society and its inclusiveness. It is also plausible, however, that the powerful search algorithms of online platforms allow people to efficiently cull for alters who are similar to themselves. If the latter proves to be the case, it means that the rise of new social media are, contrary to the conventional view, increasing class homophily and polarizing class relations. The research also has a methodological payoff. Because a network-based analysis of social class structure requires high-quality measurements of the class situation of media users, much of the research will focus on developing the methods that make such measurement possible. The social class of users and alters will be imputed by (a) linking geo-located users to their neighborhoods and housing values, (b) exploiting available profile data, (c) carrying out a lexical analysis of message content, and (d) administering surveys to users. These methods, which may be extended to carry out analogous imputations of race, gender, and other ascribed traits, will be of use to researchers in the social sciences, computer science, information science, and other disciplines facing the stock situation in which direct information on individual traits is scarce. The project will also provide new research opportunities for graduates and undergraduates at Cornell University and Stanford University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the past century, social scientists have relied heavily on surveys to obtain population data. While good for measuring demographic backgrounds and personal characteristics, surveys are a poor instrument to measure social relationships and the network of ties that form the fabric of society. Some aspects of these social networks are tedious to assess with surveys while others are simply impossible to measure. As a consequence, social interaction data are often limited to small peer groups, with no information about how these groups connect to one another.

The recent availability of social media data about online interactions and activity offer an unprecedented opportunity to observe the interactions of millions of people. While these data sources are rich in relational measures, they have very limited demographic measures such as education, race, age, gender or income. The most basic goal of our project was to develop methodologies to infer demographics for social media users. In particular, we focused on the development of measures of social class: income, occupation, and education, which are fundamental in the sociological literature.  Our specific aim was to use these data to measure how frequently people with different socioeconomic characteristics interact with one another on Facebook and Twitter. The approaches we developed enable sociologists to utilize rich new sources of data to address fundamental sociological questions using measurement from millions of people. In addition, our approach allows researchers to study the impact of demographic characteristics and social network structure on social outcomes. 

The ever-increasing volume of information about human activity and interaction creates new scientific and economic opportunities. Organizations depend on the availability of a technically skilled workforce to take advantage of these opportunities. Both graduate and undergraduate students developed in-demand, specialized skill through participation in this project. This grant provided research experience and supported mentorship for several undergraduates, including women in STEM fields and work-study eligible students. Undergraduates developed skills in technical data analysis, practical computer programming and big data techniques. Some undergraduate project alumni entered research-focused advanced degree programs while others found internship and employment opportunities in finance and technical sectors. Graduate students employed advances in computational and information sciences and leveraged new sources of data to investigate complex social phenomena. Graduate alumni transitioned to technically-focused postdocs and research positions in social media companies.

The following papers developed from work on this grant:

  1. An examination of class homophily in Twitter and Facebook (with race/ethnicty controls), including a description of the methodological innovations produced under this grant.
  2. An analysis of the impact of demographic similarity on the operation of triadic closure on the Twitter social network.
  3. A methodological paper detailing techniques to estimate group homophily levels from biased samples. 

In addition, this grant supported the development of the following techniques and datasets:

  1. Refined a technique for estimating a user's home location from a log of GPS coordinates. Our technique is an advancement over techniques used in similar research and will be described in a future paper.
  2. Invented a technique to correct estimates of group interaction rates when group labels are produced by an imperfect automatic classifier. Automatic classifiers are rarely error free, so this new technique advances the practice of using machine learning for social science research. This methodology contributes to the findings in a substantive paper and will be described in a separate future paper.
  3. Produced a data set of Twitter accounts labeled with location information from GIS and real estate databases. The Twitter account information is based on a subset of the data set collected under NSF grant SES-1226483. This data set supports a training and testing machine learning models in present and future work.
